job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: the people the animals the sense of pride
cons: management can overlook on issues like bullying

review_title: Not a company I would recommend
job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Coordinator in London, England
pros: Pay in this position is the better pay of local charities, the company gets lots of funding and has a good online system for the actually work
cons: The team is very cliquey, the team leaders act like school girls and will punish you if you do something they don’t like - if you aren’t in their favours you will get the most problems. The company itself is very backwards for a rescue charity, the new ideal is “we’re not here to save lives, we’re here to rehome”. Last year the company pts 25% of dogs. management will make decisions on pts without actually listening fully to kennel staff and have actually re-written dogs behaviours to favours them being pts. They don’t consider continued training with dogs, it’s all short term stays that can create the highest turnover. It’s all about the money not the actual dogs or cats. Cats are pts if they don’t learn to use a litter tray in a week. Very difficult to progress as it’s up to your team leads on weather you can do training and shadow other departments

review_title: Discriminate against part time workers needlessly
job_title: Marketing Manager in London, England
pros: Have good intentions Nice cause Attracts nice people as any charity would
cons: They treated my colleague who performed well terribly, essentially asking her to go full time or leave despite her being a carer and "supporting inclusion" I would like to go part time in the future but have made it clear to others that no scope for progression which worries me Very little audience data and woolly evidence of efficacy of large spending campaigns Inefficiently spend money based on what suits narrative to trustees vs what is right

job_title: Procurement Coordinator in London, England
pros: Nice cats and dogs and some okay people
cons: Bad management. Little structure lack of guidance

job_title: Operations Team in London, England
pros: Good junior colleagues. Improving facilities
cons: Remember a few years ago when Battersea dropped the "Dogs and Cats Home" bit from their name? I think that's the point at which the mission statement became "being Battersea" and the dogs and cats were seen as a hindrance. Huge number of staff dedicated to non-animal work, in comparison to other charities. , No exit interviews! No wonder you have such a hefty Glassdoor presence.

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Coordinator in London, England
pros: Amazing animals, some great people and good animal welfare.
cons: Low pay, toxic working environment, systemic culture of bullying

review_title: Friendly and welcoming environment, with a shared passion!
job_title: Personal Assistant to Director in London, England
pros: - Welcoming and very friendly environment from day one - Everyone shares the same passion for dogs and cats - Opportunities to 'cat sit' at lunchtimes
cons: - Not particularly flexible working arrangements (although may have changed now) - Not as much 'hands on' time with dogs as I would have wished for!

review_title: Fantastic front line staff. Terrible managers
job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant in London, England
pros: Wonderful team of front line rehomers and welfare staff. They give excellent care to all the cats.
cons: The worst managers I have ever worked with. Micro manage front line staff. Favouritism is rife, as is bullying by untrustworthy managers. Promotion is only given to the staff liked by the management.

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant in London, England
pros: Rescuing and looking after animals Respected charity Celebrity visits
cons: Poor management Bullying culture Wasteful with donor money Animal Welfare often comes second Would rather hire external than allow staff to progress

job_title: Administrative in London, England
pros:
Compared to other organisations I've gone to work for after my employment at Battersea, overall Battersea wasn't a a great place to work for.
For the positives paid staff and volunteers were extremely committed to the cause, friendly and hard working.
cons: It became very cold and corporate, entirely lost the lovely community feel it used to have. There were great, approachable and responsible managers, some others consistently fostered a highly toxic team culture.

review_title: Great place but doesn't value talented staff
job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros:
Nice environment and positive cause
Many good, talented hard-working colleagues
Opportunities to foster/socialise with animals on site
cons:
Poor decision-making and leadership at director level
Zero progression for existing staff and no value placed on their dedication to the organisation or talent and skills
Can sometimes be a bit stuck in the past focussing on former glories rather than trying to get ahead of the curve and embrace the future
Becoming increasingly corporate in terms of office culture

job_title: Direct Marketing Executive in London, England
pros: Shared love of animals, the passion for animal care was immediately obvious and rippled through every employee. The majority of colleagues were friendly, welcoming and supportive.
cons: staff who had been their for years were stuck in the mud, not forward-thinking and made it known they had 'favourites'

review_title: Some great people but many day to day limitations
job_title: Canine Behaviourist and Training Advisor in Old Windsor, England
pros:
lovely and dedicated people 
good pay for the charity sector
beautiful site
cons:
zero opportunities for flexible working hours
senior management tended to micromanage
mentally draining

job_title: Kennel Technician in London, England
pros: You get to work with dogs
cons: Can be hard on your back

review_title: RVN at Battersea Dogs and Cats Home
job_title: Registered Veterinary Nurse in London, England
pros:
- Great pay and benefits
- Working sociable hours
- Managers are very helpful and understanding in dealing with personal issues
- Facilities are very modern; very spacious kennels for both cats and dogs
- Workers are very dedicated
cons:
- Animals are left alone overnight, even after invasive surgical procedures
- No team meetings; poor communication between managers and the rest of the team
- Lack of diversity at all levels
- Poor communication between different departments of the home, and frequent misunderstandings due to this
- Poor career progression opportunities
- Very old fashioned standards of care; management is reluctant to make any changes 
- Management can be cliquy

job_title: Anonymous Employee in London, England
pros: Really love people and great cause
cons: No progression and low pay

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant in London, England
pros: Spend all day with dogs
cons: Management, Pay, treated by others

job_title: Canine Behaviourist and Training Advisor in London, England
pros: Great organisation, good benefits, dedicated staff
cons: Found management difficult - tended to micromanage

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant in Sevenoaks, England
pros: Very positive and supporting environment with people who care a lot about dogs and cats!
cons: Long working hours as expected in animal field. Not a lot of cons, great charity!

job_title: Compliance Assistant in London, England
pros: Mostly really wonderful people, caring company environment. The senior staff are involved and in tune.
cons: As with many charities, bullying can be an issue among colleagues

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Coordinator in London, England
pros: Passionate staff, opportunities for development.
cons: Can be a lack of flexibility in work/life balance.

job_title: Officer in London, England
pros: great people, great culture - lovely!
cons: none - really amazing place to be

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant Level I in Old Windsor, England
pros: You get to play with cute dogs
cons: Very emotionally draining and physically too. Management have no respect for you and you receive no help

review_title: Best charity I have worked out
job_title: Corporate Partnerships Executive in London, England
pros:
Extremely focused fundraising team with ambitious but achievable targets. 

Exciting place to work 

Strong culture and close teams who are 'in it together' 

Strong leadership that listens to you and values your input no matter what level you are working at. 

Dogs in the office 

The cause is on site (dogs &a cats) so helps focus your fundraising and igniting your passion constantly. 

They hire incredibly nice people and you feel part of the Battersea 'family'
cons: Presence is in the south and south east so can be difficult to get support from further afield in the U.K. (Although this is not unachievable, just makes for more of a challenge)

review_title: Dream job ruined by poor leadership
job_title: Anonymous in London, England
pros: The animals. My immediate team. The grass roots and community work we did. Great cause.
cons:
Poor leadership. Department head was one of the most uninspiring leaders I’ve ever worked with. Rude. Unenthusiastic. Stuck in the dark ages. 
Complaints to HR were never taken seriously so nothing was ever done about why people were leaving.  
Lack of diversity at all levels. 
Hardest working people are the ones paid the least. Was shocked when I found out the salaries for kennel staff. 
Sycophantic behaviour towards famous people.

job_title: Human Resources in London, England
pros: People so dedicated and all lovely. Dogs everywhere and in offices too so all staff get to spend time and do our bit for dogs. managers strong and work hard, ceo passionate and inclusive, directors fun and engaged and we are all trying to make the charity better all the time. Volunteers very dedicated and help in most teams. Cats sometimes take second place to dogs but chattery team are brilliant.
cons: Fast moving and busy, fund raising  team turn over people quickly if they don’t do well and catch up by HR being done too slowly

review_title: A great place to work if you want to be alongside great colleagues and love cats or dogs.
job_title: Head Of Operations in London, England
pros: The people who work here are friendly and all really care about the work they do. Same for all the volunteers. Being able to say you help animals is amazing- especially seeing them go out to their new homes. Dogs in offices and a cheap cafe is nice too xx
cons: With massive highs also come some emotional lows as we can't always help every single animal that comes to us, despite trying very hard. Working with supportive colleagues helps.

job_title: in London, England
pros:
Good people atmosphere , love seeing dogs and cats each day.
Excellence animal handling and welfare at all cost
cons:
Poor management decision and prioritisation
New processes to streamline and improve have been ignored.
Need for improvement to innovate.

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant in London, England
pros: The most rewarding job I have ever done, knowing that you are surrounded by people brought together by their common love of animals and commitment to ensure animal welfare.
cons: when you hear heart breaking stories of dogs and cats

job_title: Rehoming and Welfare Assistant Level I in London, England
pros: All of the staff are incredible and it's so rewarding seeing the difference we make to the dogs on a daily basis.
cons: There are lots of stairs!

job_title: Retail in London, England
pros: I love animals and I really don’t like seeing them hurt and sad
cons: Learning more and knowing more this I didn’t know

job_title: Developer in Wilmslow, England
pros: extremely good place to work
cons: seems to have shrunk a bit recently

job_title: Customer Service in London, England
pros: Working with dogs and cats is very rewarding
cons: Working weekends can be stressful.
